Variation Example: Two lovers are not allowed to live together. They die of grief (commit suicide) & are buried side by side (in the same cemetery). Plants grow from their graves; the branches intertwine (meet over the roof of the church). Thus the lovers are united in death.

Classifications: Man as Sacrifice to the Storm
Variation Example: A ship is in the middle of a dangerous storm. One man on board, an apparent evil-doer, seems to be the cause for the distress at sea. He has to be identified & thrown overboard to placate the storm. The sinner is found by casting lots (throwing dice), & when he is thrown into the sea the storm abates. In some (Christian) variants the guilty person confesses his deed voluntarily, whereupon the storm abates (supernatural deliverance of the victim).

In the absence of her husband (lover) who is far away on a journey (in prison), a woman is forced to choose another husband. The first husband (disguised, as beggar) returns (with supernatural help, carried during a deep sleep, warned by a dream) on the wedding day & discloses his identity to his wife (by a ring well known to her), is recognized by domestic animals (horse, dog), or answers the woman’s questions correctly (concerning features of the house or birthmarks). The revenge on the rival follows.

On their wedding night, a man allows his bride to visit her former lover (fiancée), in order to keep a promise she had made previously (to cancel the engagement). On her way she meets a robber. When she tells him her story he leaves her unmolested. When her lover (fian-cée) hears about her bridegroom’s (the robber’s) magnanimity, he takes her back to her bridegroom without touching her. In some variants the tale occurs in conjunction with a frame tale that deals with the discovery of a thief: Three (four) sons inherit jew el ry (money) from their father (merchants bury their fortune). The money is stolen by one of the brothers (merchants). The robbed owners call a wise man (judge, king, Solomon), who is to discover the thief. The wise man (his daughter) then starts to tell the story (see above). The thief betrays himself unconsciously when he answers the question, “Who acted in the noblest way?” He argues that the robber in the story was the most noble one (he answers other questions in a revealing manner).

Classifications: The Youth in the Land of the Cheaters
Variation Example: A young man sets out on busi-ness & comes to a land where cheaters flourish. After a while he loses all his goods. A one-eyed man (woman) states that the youth’s father had taken the other eye & demands compensation. The same with a one-legged man, who states that the youth’s father had once taken his other leg & now asks for compensation. A barber agrees to shave the young man for “something” & then demands a huge sum of money (other valuables). Finally the young man is rescued from his difficult situation by someone (his wife, another person) who outwits the cheaters & recovers her husband’s lost property. The rescuer demands that the one-eyed man should give up his remaining eye so that he could match it with the other. In the same way he demands the remaining leg of the one-legged man, in order to compare it with the other one. The rescuer tricks the barber into accepting “something” for his service.

This miscellanous type comprises various tales dealing with ungrateful children (son, daughter-in-law) of an ageing father. They think about & eventually change their behavior because of the analogous actions of their own son (daughter). (1) When an aged father is banned from the table & served his meals in a wooden cup by his son & his daughter-in-law, the little grandson starts to build a similar cup for his parents to use when they grow old. Thereupon the couple starts to reflect on their undig-ni fied behavior. Thinking of their own old age, they bring the old father back to the family table. (2) A son gives his father half a blanket (carpet, cape, cloth) to keep warm. Thereupon the little grandson keeps the other half of the blanket & explains that he will save it for his parents for when they are old. (3) An aged father is abandoned by his son in the wilderness (abyss) in a cart (sledge, basket). The grandson keeps it in order to use it in the same way for his parents when they have grown old. They reflect on their behavior. (4) The ungrateful son drags his old father out of the house by pulling at his hair. At the threshold the father says, “Do not drag me further; I dragged my own father only this far!”. The son reflects on his bad behavior.

Persuaded by a painter, a king (landlord) orders his architect to build a tower for the architect (the king himself) to go to heaven to see his father (to build a mansion up there). The architect leaves through an underground passage. He entices the painter to climb up to heaven. But the painter (king, landlord) meets his death when the tower burns.

Classifications: Meat Springs as a Toad on the Face of an Ungrateful Son
Variation Example: A couple (son) intends to eat a roasted chicken (meal). When the man’s old father passes by unexpectedly, they hide the chicken in order not to share it with him. The old man takes a drink & then continues on his way. When they replace the chicken on the table in order to have their meal, it has turned into a toad (snake) & jumps onto the son’s face where it stays until his death.

Classifications: Wisdom of Hidden Old Man Saves Kingdom
Variation Example: During a famine (war), the young people have an assembly & decide (the emperor orders) that all old & seemingly useless men should be killed. One man hides his father. When everything goes wrong under the young rulers, the wise old man comes forth & saves the situation with his good advice (he helps perform difficult tasks with his wisdom). Thereupon he is honored & the custom of killing old people is aban doned. In some variants the son, who intends to kill his father, realizes that the same will happen to him when he is old, & lets his father live.

A wise king, asked by his brother (Damocles, courtier, court jester) why he always looks sad even in happy situations, answers the question by sending for the questioner & pretending to plan his execution. The brother is placed on a chair over a pit filled with red-hot coals, with four lances pointing at him & a sword (stone, millstone) suspended over his head on horse’s hair (thread). The king explains that this situation resembles his own: the pit stands for the fire in hell, the lances for death & the sword signifies the divine judge. This is the reason for his sadness & fear.

Trusting to his children’s care when he is old, a rich man leaves all his property to them. They soon forget their intentions & neglect their father. Thereupon the old man plans a ruse: He starts counting money conspicuously & points to a chest giving the advice that it contains another considerable inheritance. Thereupon the children change their behavior & look after their father carefully. When the father finally dies they find only sand & stones in the chest. In some variants they find a mace with the advice that it should be used to kill anyone stupid enough to give away his inheritance before his death.

Classifications: The Dishes of the Same Flavor
Variation Example: A virtuous woman (virgin, wife, widow ) tries to escape from the attentions of a mighty man (king, ruler). She serves him dishes that look different but taste identical (different colored eggs, same drinks in different glasses). In response to his question what this means, she compares the dishes with women: Even if they look different, they are all alike. This is why it is not worthwhile to change sexual partners. The man is dissuaded from his amorous purpose & contents himself with his own wife.

In accordance with his wife’s wish, a king gives orders to build a palace made of bird bones. One bird comes late, & when it arrives, it says it was thinking about whether men or women were worth more. It decided that women must be worth more because those who obey women are subordinate to them. The king rescinds his order.

Classifications: Brother Chosen Rather than Husband or Son
Variation Example: Three men are condemn ed to death. A woman appeals to the ruler for clemency, ex-plain ing that they are her brother, her husband & her son. When the ruler agrees to release only one of them, she chooses her brother, because she is still young enough to marry again & give birth to another son. Only a brother cannot be replaced. Impressed by her explanation (ruse, logic), the ruler frees all three men (brother & son, the brother alone).

A man (woman) condemned to starvation is closely guarded. Only his daughter has permission to visit him daily, but before her visit she is always checked thoroughly so that she cannot bring any food. After a long time the condemned man shows no signs of exhaustion. One day the guardians observe that the daughter suckles her father through a crack in the prison wall (woman suckles son, wife suckles strange man, daughter suckles mother). Impressed by the woman’s devotion, the judges release the prisoner.

An official who desires a certain woman agrees to set her husband (brother) free from prison if she will sleep with him. She complies, but her husband is to be executed anyway. When the wife brings a suit against the official, the ruler restores her honor by marrying her to the official. Later the official is executed & his wife receives his property.

A king marries his daughter to a lazy man (mother’s boy, beggar). Forced by his wife to work, he joins a caravan. In the desert he climbs into a well in order to fetch water. He finds a kidnapped girl (princess) & a pomegranate. He sends the pomegranate to his wife, & out of it fall jewels. She becomes rich & builds a palace. He returns the kidnapped girl to her father & returns home to his wife.

Classifications: False Magician Exposed by Clever Girl
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A magician deceives the eyes of spectators making them be-lieve that a rooster can pull (carry) a heavy beam (a rope-dancer can push a cart, juggle a beam). A girl with a four-leafed shamrock (snake, dead toad, salamander) understands the trick & states that the rooster can only pull straw. The magician takes revenge by making the girl believe she is going through deep water. She raises her dress as high as possible & all spectators mock her. (A lock magically closes the girl’s mouth so that she cannot speak.) (2) A juggler pretends to be able to creep through a thick beam (stone). The girl with the shamrock discovers that he only creeps over it or next to it. The water-episode follows, & in some variants the girl is bewitched into being lame or crooked.

A woman becomes ill during an epidemic & falls into a deathlike faint. Her husband orders her buried & puts a precious ring (clothes) into her coffin. One of the grave-diggers returns to the cemetery at night, reopens the grave, & tries to rob the dead. Thereupon (when he tries to cut her finger) the woman revives, leaves the grave, & returns home to her husband. He receives her kindly & they continue to live together for a long time in good health.

A knight woos a married woman. The husband kills his wife’s lover (suitor) & orders the cook to prepare his heart & to serve it to his wife. When she praises the meal, he tells her what she has eaten, remarking that her lover pleases her dead as well as alive. Thereupon she jumps out the window (refuses any food, dies from pain). The husband regrets his deed (is punished by the ruler, by the woman’s relatives).

A merchant admires a sovereign who in-vites him to his castle. At dinner the merchant observes that the sovereign’s wife is served her meal in a skull (her lover’s head with beard). In his bedroom he finds two dead young men hanging. The sovereign explains to him that his wife had committed adultery with a duke whereupon he had him beheaded. In return, the son of the duke killed the two young men. As penance, the woman has to eat from the skull, & the two corpses are a reminder of the murder.

A farmhand (poor boy, strong man, three sons one after another) agrees to a contest with his master (devil, ogre, priest) that whoever becomes angry first (before the cuckoo calls) must allow strip(s) of skin (flesh) to be cut out of his back (have his nose or ears cut off, be beaten) or must pay a large sum of money. The farmhand (third son) heaps abuse on his master or feigns stupidity until the latter erupts in anger. The master tries to flee but finally must take his punishment.

The devil’s helper has to cut some trees for firewood, but his axe does not split the wood (the woodpile becomes larger with every cut). The helper finds a cat (snake) in the pile, kills it, & then is able to finish his work.
A farmhand harms his master (ogre, priest) by destroying (selling, giving away, exchanging) his property.

A master (ogre, devil) bids his farmhand to plow following the dog (as long as the dog sits still), & to take the horses wherever the dog goes. The farmhand plows over hill & dale. (He beats the dog.) The dog runs home & enters the stable through a small aperture (hole in the wall). To take the horses in the same way, the farmhand cuts them into quarters. In some variants, a farmhand must guard the cattle. In the evening he will get his dinner only if he comes home before the dog. Dur ing the first few days, the farmhand does not get dinner. Then he kills the dog.

Classifications: Hogs in the mud; sheep in the air
Variation Example: This tale exists chiefly in three different forms: (1) Left to guard the pigs (cows, horses), a farmhand sells them but sticks their severed tails in the muddy ground. His master pulls the tails out & thinks that the pigs are sunk in the mud (have escaped underground). (2) A farmhand sells his master’s sheep & hangs their severed tails (bells) in a tree. He thus makes the master believe that the sheep have been carried away by a strong wind (have escaped into the air, have gone to heaven). (3) A farmhand (thief) kills one ox & puts its tail in the mouth of another, so that his master (the owner of the ox) thinks one ox has eaten the other.
An ogre orders a man to build a bridge (road) not of wood, stone, iron, or earth. The man slaughters all the ogre’s livestock & builds the bridge out of their carcasses.

A farmhand is ordered by his master to “cast an eye” over something (somebody). He intentionally takes this request lit erally, kills the master’s livestock, & throws the animals’ eyes at the object (person), where the misunderstanding is unintentional.

Classifications: Kill the Sheep That is Looking at You
Variation Example: A farmhand is told by his master (devil) to kill the sheep that looks at him first. The whole flock looks at him, so that the farmhand kills all the animals.

Classifications: Other Means of Killing or Maiming Livestock
Variation Example: Misc. type with diverse variants, e.g.: A farmhand is ordered by his master to pasture the cattle in such a way that they come home dancing & laughing, so he makes them limp & tears off their lips. A farmhand frightens his master’s oxen on a bridge so that they drown. A farmhand removes the skin of oxen’s legs so that they will not get them wet while drinking.
A farmhand is ordered by his master to light the road (paint the house red). He sets the house on fire.

A farmhand (foolish man or woman) is ordered to guard the door of the store-room (house). He pulls the door off its hinges & carries it with him. In some variants, a farmhand is asked to close the door tightly. He uses iron nails in order to do so.

A farmhand is ordered to repair the house (tidy up the rooms, rebuild the dunghill, fill up a well). He takes all the objects outside (tears out the stove or the floor, smashes the furniture or the dishes, carries everything to the dunghill, throws it into the well, etc.). In some variants, the farmhand is told to do what the neighbors do. He tears off the roof (destroys the house).
A farmhand is told to cut wood. He cuts down a neighbor’s orchard (vineyard).
A farmhand is ordered by his master to wash the child. He holds the child under water until it is drowned (cleans the child outside & inside: takes the intestines out & washes them).
A farmhand is ordered to bathe (warm) the grandmother. He scalds her or puts her on (into) the stove.

A man (boy) wants to (is expected to) learn how to forge metal objects simply by watching the smith. After a while (three years) he finishes his “apprenticeship”. As his first piece, he wants to forge a plowshare for a farmer (his uncle). He hammers so powerfully that the iron becomes too thin for a plowshare. So he decides to forge an axe instead. This does not work out, either. From the rest of the iron, he tries to forge a knife & after that an awl. Finally only a tiny piece of iron is left. He tells the farmer that he will forge him a hiss & throws the iron into water, where it sinks hissing. In some variants, a farmhand is ordered to whet a knife. He whets the whole blade away.

A master (devil) asks his farmhand to clean the horse(s). The farmhand cuts off the horse’s tail (mane, etc.) (washes the horse in boiling water, curries it with a sharp razor). In some variants, the farmhand cleans the horses both outside & inside: He takes their intestines out & washes them.

Classifications: Covering the Whole Wagon with Tar
Variation Example: A master (devil) tells his farmhand to grease the wagon. The farmhand covers the whole wagon (the inside of the wagon) with tar.

Classifications: The Woman as Cuckoo in the Tree
Variation Example: The anger bargain between a master (ogre) & his farmhand is to end when the cuckoo calls. In order to hasten the contract’s end, the master’s wife climbs into a tree & imitates the cuckoo. The farmhand recognizes the trick & shoots (throws a stone) at the “bird”. The woman is killed.
